major através de mecanismo dependente de contato e de TGF- β
Corroborando esse fato, o mesmo grupo mostrou que a depleção de neutrófilos no modelo BALB/c in vivo (susceptível), reduz a carga paras itária, mas exacerba a lesão por L
major em camundongos resistentes (C57B l/6)
Neutrófilos deste último camundongo promovem a destruição de Leishmania por macrófagos por mecanismo dependente de TNF- α (RIBEIRO-GOMES et al

Essa produção de TNF- α parece ser dependente da produção de elastase pelos ne utrófilos inflamatórios de C 57Bl/6, que liberam mais desta serina protease do que os neutró filos de BALB/c (RIBEIRO-GOMES et al
Este mesmo grupo demonstrou ainda que a atividad e microbicida estimulada em macrófagos pela elastase dos neutrófilos depende da expressão de receptor TLR4 (RIBEIRO- GOMES et al, 2007)
A liberação das NETs pelos ne utrófilos seria uma forma diferente de liberação da elastase

Afonso e colaboradores (2008), observar am que a fagocitose de neutrófilos apoptóticos por macrófagos infectados com L. amazonensis implica em um aumento na carga parasitária de forma dependente da produção de TGF- 1 e PGE 2. Ao contrário, a fagocitose de neutrófilos necróticos induz a morte dos parasitos dentro dos macrófagos via TNF- α e elastase neutrofílica. Essa intera ção entre macrófagos infectados com neutrófilos necróticos resulta em alta produ ção de superóxidos e não gera aumento na produção de óxido nítrico.

Todos esses achados sugerem que na leishmaniose, macrófagos e neutrófilos possuem papel importante no curso da doença. Entretanto, comparado aos macrófagos, o papel dos neutrófilos na imunidade contra a Leishmania ainda é pouco claro e estudado.

1.3.1 As NETs na infecção por protozoários Apesar de não ter sido descrito uma i ndução direta na formação de NETs por Plasmodium , foi demonstrada a presença das NETs em sangue de crianças infectadas por Plasmodium falciparum . Hemácias infectadas e tr ofozoítas interagindo com as redes, foram detectadas por coloração para DNA (BAKER et al., 2008). Behrendt e colaboradores re portaram que esporozoítas de Eimeria bovis induzem a formação de NETs de neutrófilo s de bezerros. Não foi demonstrado um efeito tóxico direto das NETs para o pr otozoário em questão, mas a capacidade do parasito infectar células endoteliais primárias foi diminuída em comparação aos parasitos não tratados com NETs (BEHRENDT et al., 2009). Abi Abdallah e colaboradores demonstraram que o protozoário Toxoplasma gondii ativa a produção de NETs de neutrófilos de camundongo. Este processo é independente da invasão da cé lula, tendo em vista que o tr atamento com citocalasina D não impediu a liberação das NETs. Seguindo o padrão de interação entre microrganismos e NETs, estes parasitos inte ragem, são presos e uma parte da população morre. A adição de DNAse restaura a viabilid ade do parasito aos níveis do controle. Em um modelo in vivo de infecção pulmonar por Toxoplasma , o grupo demonstrou um rápido influxo de neutrófilos no pulmão que se correlaciona com a quantidade de DNA fita dupla detectado no lavado bronqueoalveolar. A depleção de neutrófilos resulta em um aumento no número de parasitos viávei s recuperados do pulmão em comparação aos camundongos que não tiveram neutróf ilos depletados (ABI ABDALLAH et al., 2012). Em 2009 nosso grupo relatou pela primeira vez a interação entre neutrófilos purificados de sangue humano com Leishmania tendo como objeto de estudo a formação das redes extracelulares (GUIMARÃES-COSTA et al ., 2009). Em um primeiro momento, investigamos o poder de adesão de promastigotas de Leishmania amazonensis a NETs pré-formadas. Após ativ ação de neutrófilos com PMA, visualizamos, por microscopia de fluorescên cia, NETs prendendo os promastigotas. O próximo passo foi verificar se os promastigot as eram capazes de estimular a liberação de NETs em neutrófilos naive. Estruturas em forma de rede, marcadas com corante para DNA, principal componente das NETs, e com anticorpos específicos para histona e elastase foram observadas nas preparações, co m estes três component es se sobrepondo na mesma estrutura (GUIMARÃES-COSTA et al., 2009).

Nossos resultados demonstrando que promastigotas eram observados associados às NETs nos ensaios de fluorescência nos le varam a analisar aspectos ultraestruturais  desta interação utilizando microscopia el etrônica de varredura. Desta forma, visualizamos também a íntima interação entr e os parasitos e as redes extracelulares (GUIMARÃES-COSTA et al., 2009).

Tendo em vista esse perfil indutor exerci do pelo contato parasito-neutrófilo, analisamos a espécie-especificidade da NETose induzida por promastigotas de L. amazonesis quantificamos a concentração de DNA, constituinte das NETs, no sobrenadante da interação de neut rófilos naive com promastigotas de L. chagasi e L. major . Nossos resultados demonstram que a indução de NETose é dose dependente já que quanto mais parasitos são incubados co m neutrófilos maior a liberação de DNA para o meio extracelular. Além disso, e ssa indução é uma característica comum à diferentes espécies de Leishmania . Usando o mesmo protocolo, incubamos neutrófilos com amastigotas de L. amazonensis , a forma do parasito que mantém a infecção no hospedeiro vertebrado, que também foram capazes de estimular a liberação das redes por neutrófilos humanos (GUIMARÃES-COSTA et al., 2009).

Promastigotas de todas as espécies de Leishmania sintetizam lipofosfoglicano (LPG), um glicoconjugado que recobre toda a superfície do para sito, sendo, portanto, uma das primeiras moléculas a entrar em contato com as células do hospedeiro. Quantificamos então a concentração de NET-DNA no sobrenadante de neutrófilos incubados com LP G purificado de Leishmania amazonensis . LPG também ativou a formação das NETs de forma dose-dependente; a quantidade de DNA quando os neutrófilos foram incubados com 10 µg/mL de LPG foi o dobro da quantidade de DNA no sobrenadante dos neutrófilo s controle (GUIMARÃES-COSTA et al., 2009). A seguir avaliamos a toxicidade das NETs para os promastigotas de Leishmania amazonensis . Para distinguir atividade fagocítica da atividade microbicida exercida pelas NETs, neutrófilos foram incubados com citocalasina D, um inibidor de fagocitose e, assim, permitindo medir a morte extracel ular. Da mesma forma adicionamos DNase às culturas para romper as NETs e, dessa forma, poder avaliar a morte intracelular. A sobrevivência dos parasitos aumentou em 39% e 60% acima do controle quando neutrófilos foram tratados com citocalasina D e DNase, respectivamente, indicando um papel tóxico das redes para os parasitos. Quando simultaneamente tratamos neutrófilos com citocalasina D e DNase, a sobreviv ência dos promastigotas aumentou 140% quando comparada ao controle. Além disso, de monstramos que as histonas, presentes nas NETs, participam da toxicidade pa ra os promastigotas (GUIMARÃES-COSTA et  A fim de confirmar a presença das NETs in vivo , biópsias de pacientes com leishmaniose cutânea foram analisadas. NETs foram observadas tanto em áreas de cicatrização como em áreas de infiltrado infl amatório apresentando vários neutrófilos. Visualizamos a presença de estruturas marcadas com anticorpos anti-elastase e anti-histona e com corante intercal ante de DNA (GUIMARÃES-COSTA et al., 2009). Gabriel e colaboradores (2010), confir maram nossos dados ao mostrar que promastigotas de L. donovani também induzem a liberação de NETs de neutrófilos humanos, são presos por estas estruturas, porém resistem à morte mediada pela NET. Essa resistência deve-se ao lipofosfoglica no, glicoconjugado majoritário presente em toda a superfície do parasito. Ao contrário dos nossos resultados, o grupo afirma que LPG não induz a formação de NETs. Além disso, a inibição da produção de ROS por DPI não inibiu a formação das redes, evidenciando mecanismo de indução de NETs desencadeado pelo parasito indepe ndente da geração de ROS (GABRIEL et al., 2010). Chagas e colaboradores (2014) recentemen te demonstraram que a saliva destes insetos possui uma endonuclease que cliva as redes extracelulare s de neutrófilos induzidas por L. major . Em um modelo de infecção in vivo , o grupo demonstrou que a inoculação de parasitos com a nuclease au menta a infecção, sugerindo que as NETs possuem um papel microbicida importante in vivo (CHAGAS et al., 2014). Por anos os estudos da re sposta imune ao parasito Leishmania focaram-se no papel da resposta adaptativa e dos macróf agos durante a infecção. Contudo, na última década, os estudos sobre o papel dos neutró filos nos eventos inic iais pós-infecção vem ganhando força e, hoje, sabemos que os neut rófilos desempenham papel fundamental na infecção. O estudo da netose durante doenças infecciosas ainda é relativamente recente e pouco se sabe sobre o papel da s NETs durante a infecção por Leishmania . Nosso grupo demonstrou que o parasito é capaz de i nduzir a liberação das redes extracelulares de neutrófilos. Além disso, o parasito interage e é morto pelas NETs. O objetivo fundamental desta tese é contribuir pa ra a identificação de novos mecanismos envolvidos na resposta imune inata na leis hmaniose. Essencialmente, este estudo visa esclarecer o papel de neut rófilos na infecção por Leishmania , analisando especialmente as redes extracelulares de ne utrófilos (NETs) em ensaios in vitro usando neutrófilos humanos.

2. OBJETIVO GERAL Neste trabalho, propomos avaliar se a 3’ nucleotidase/nucl ease expressa na membrana das formas promastigotas pode constituir um mecanismo de escape dos parasitos a este mecanismo. Além disso, aval iamos a influência das NETs na modulação dos mecanismos efetores de monócitos humanos. 2.1 OBJETIVOS ESPECÍFICOS
Como objetivos específicos, nosso proj eto se propôs a analisar a (o) (s):

A. Produção de NETs por neutrófilos huma nos em resposta aos promastigotas de Leishmania infantum ; B. Papel da 3’nucleotidase/nuc lease na indução das NETs; C. Papel da 3’nucleotidase/nuclease na sobrevivência dos parasitos; D. Efeito das NETs no processo de diferenciação de monócitos humanos em células dendríticas imaturas; E. Características morfo-fenotípicas dos monócitos diferenciados na presença de NETs F. Expressão dos receptores de IL-4 e GM-CSF; G. Capacidade fagocítica de monócitos tratados com NETs; H. Interação entre monócitos e as NETS por microscopia de fluorescência; I. Citocinas produzidas por m onócitos tratados com NETs; J. Capacidade microbicida de m onócitos tratados com as NETs.
3. RESULTADOS

Título : ETosis: A Microbicidal Mechanisms beyond Cell Death Publicado em : Journal of Parasitology Research , volume 2012 (2012), Article ID 929743. Autores : Anderson B. Guimarães-Costa, Michelle T. C. Nascimento, Amanda B. Wardini, Lucia H. Pinto-da-Silva e Elvira M. Saraiva. Resumo : Um novo mecanismo de morte celular, chamada netose, foi recentemente descrito em neutrófilos. A ne tose ocorre quando neutrófilos são ativados por diferentes estímulos, incluindo microrganismos, e consiste na liberação de estruturas em forma de rede para o meio extracelular. Estas estruturas foram denominadas de redes extracelulares de neutrófilos (do inglês Neutrophil extracelular traps ) e servem para prender e matar microrganismos. As N ETs são compostas por DNA, histonas e proteínas de diferent es compartimentos do neutrófilo, co mo a elastase por exemplo. Os mecanismos moleculares envolvidos no processo de ativação da netose tem sido alvo de muitas pesquisas. Com todos os dados que há na literatura podemos concluir que as NETs podem ser ativadas por diferentes vi as de sinalização, dependendo do estímulo. Foi descrito que eosinófilos, mastócitos, monócitos e macrófagos liberam redes extracelulares (ETs). Microrganismos, mo léculas associadas aos microrganismos, moléculas sintéticas ou fisiológicas são capazes de ativar a netose; a lista de indutores vem crescendo desde a descoberta deste fenôm eno. Além disso, estas estruturas vêm ganhando funções e importância em diferentes doenças, infecciosas ou não. Hoje, sabe- se que as NETs não servem apenas para prender e matar os microrganismos, mas servem também para modular a resposta im une contra os mesmos. Estas redes também possuem papel importante em doenças não inf ecciosas, autoimunes, circulatórias ou até mesmo no câncer. Neste artigo nós revisamos o mecanismo da netose/etose, enfatizando o papel destas redes em doenças infecciosas causadas por protozoá rios, fungos e vírus.

Título : 3’Nucleotidase/Nuclease Activity Allows Leishmania Parasites To Escape Killing by Neutrophil Extracellular Traps Publicado em : Infection and immunity , ahead of print Autores : Anderson B. Guimarães-Costa, Thiago S. deSouza-Vieira, Rafael Palleta- Silva, Anita Leocádio Freitas-Mesquita , José Roberto Meye r-Fernandes e Elvira Saraiva.

Resumo : A leishmaniose é uma doença tropical , negligenciada e que se encontra espalhada ao redor do mundo. Esta doença é causa por parasitos do gênero Leishmania e inicia-se quando o inseto vetor, ao reali zar o repasto sanguíneo, inocula os parasitos no hospedeiro vertebrado. Estes prot ozoários expressam a enzima 3’Nucleotidase/nuclease (3’NT/NU), que foi de scrita estar associad a e ser relevante na nutrição do parasito e no estabelecimento da infecção. Foi demonstrado que bactérias que expressam ou secretam nucleases es capam dos efeito tóxicos das redes extracelulares de neutrófilos (NETs), te ndo em vista que o esqueleto das NETs é formado por DNA. Logo, neste trabalho, nós investigamos o papel da 3’NT/NU na sobrevivência do parasito com neut rófilos humanos. Promastigotas de Leishmania infantum foram crescidos em meio com alta c oncentração de fosfato (HP) ou meio com baixa concentração de fosfato (LP) para modularmos a atividade da enzima. Nós comparamos a sobrevivência dos dois grupos durante a interação com neutrófilos, analisando o papel das NETs. Como descrito anteriormente, detect amos maior atividade da enzima nos parasitos LP. Ambos os para sitos, HP e LP, foram capazes de induzir a formação das NETs, sem diferenças entre os grupos, de uma forma dose e tempo dependentes. Porém, parasitos LP sobreviveram 2,4 vezes mais que os parasitos HP. A digestão das NETs foi prevenida pelo tratamentos dos promastigotas com Tetratiomolibdato (TTM), um inibidor da 3’NT/NU. Ainda, a inibição da enzima por TTM, 3’AMP ou 5’GMP diminuíram a sobreviv ência do parasito durante a interação com neutrófilos. Nossos resultados apre sentados neste artigo demonstram que promastigotas de Leishmania infantum induzem a formação das NETs, mas conseguem evadir à morte mediada pelas NETs atravé s da atividade 3’NT/NU, dando uma nova função para esta enzima.

Título : Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) im pair monocytes differentiation into dendritic cells. Autores : Anderson B. Guimarães-Costa, Natalia C. Rochael, Fabiano Oliveira, Juliana Echevarria-Lima e Elvira M. Saraiva.

Resumo : A infecção pelo parasito Leishmania inicia-se quando o inseto vetor inocula, durante o repasto sanguíneo, o parasito no hospedeiro vertebra do. Neutrófilos e monócitos são recrutados para o sítio in feccioso, onde estas células provavelmente interagem. Os neutrófilos são as primeiras cé lulas recrutadas para o local da picada do inseto e as primeiras células parasitadas pelo parasito. Nosso grupo demonstrou que os neutrófilos liberam as redes extracelulares em resposta à Leishmania . As redes extracelulares de neutrófilos (NETs) são es truturas em forma de rede, compostas por DNA, histona e proteínas de grânulos e citoplasmáticas, que prendem e matam uma parte da população de parasitos. Os monócitos podem se diferenciar em células dendríticas ou macrófagos, dependendo do microa mbiente que se encontram. As células dendríticas derivadas de monócitos possuem papel importante no desenvolvimento de uma resposta Th1 protetora durante a infecção por Leishmania . Nossa hipótese é de que os neutrófilos são recrutados e in teragem com os promastigotas de Leishmania , liberando NETs. Em seguida, monócitos são recrutados para o local da infecção e interagem com as NETs e o parasito. Nest e trabalho nós investigamos o impacto das NETs na diferenciação de monócitos em células dendríticas e a res posta destas células ao parasito. Através de imagens de micr oscopia de fluorescência observamos que as NETs interagem com os monócitos, e demonstramos que monócitos tratados com sobrenadantes enriquecidos em NETs não se diferenciam em células dendríticas imaturas. O pré-tratamento das NETs com DNase, clivando a estrutura das redes, reverte o efeito inibitório e os monócito s passam a se diferenciar em DCs como o controle. Utilizando técnicas de citometria e PCR em tempo real, observamos que monócitos tratados com NETs apresentam a expressão do receptor de interleucina 4 diminuída, mecanismo pelo qual não se diferenciam em células dendríticas. Além disso, observamos, por microscopia e citometria de fluxo, que os monócitos tratados com NETs diferenciam-se em macrófagos. Por fim, monócitos tratados com NETs matam menos o parasito em comparação aos monócitos não tratados. Nossos resultados  demonstram que as NETs interferem na resposta de monócitos ao parasito Leishmania , diminuindo a diferenciação destas células em DCs e a capacidade leishmanicida dos macrófagos.

Rochael1, Fabiano Oliveira2, Juliana Echevarria-Lima1# and Elvira M. Saraiva1# Departamento de Imunologia, Instituto de Microbiologia Paulo de Góes, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Ri o de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil. 2Vector Molecular Biology Section, Laboratory of Malaria and Vector Research, Nationa l Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, National Institut es of Health, Rockville, Maryland, USA Summary Sentence : Neutrophil extracellu lar traps downregulate the expression of interleukin 4 receptor, impairing monocytes to fully differentiate into dendritic cells. Running title : NETs impact monocyte’s response to Leishmania .

# Corresponding authors: Dr. Juliana Ec hevarria-Lima and Dr. Elvira Saraiva Dr. Juliana Echevarria-Lima Laboratório de Imunologi a Básica e Aplicada Departamento de Imunologia Instituto de Microbio logia Paulo de Góes Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro Centro de Ciências da Saúde (CCS), Bloco D, sala D0-35 21941-902 - Rio de Janeiro, RJ - Brazil Phone (55 21) 2562 6748 e-mail: juechevarria@micro.ufrj.br Dr. Elvira Maria Saraiva Departamento de Imunologia Instituto de Microbiolo gia Paulo de Góes Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro Centro de Ciências da Saúde (CCS), Bloco D, sala D0-44 esaraiva@micro.ufrj.br  Abstract Background : Neutrophils and monocytes are recrui ted to the site of infection by Leishmania . Leishmania parasites induce the release and are killed by Neutrophil Extracellular Traps (NETs), but some parasites escape NET-mediated killing. During the infection, monocytes-derived dendritic cells were demons trated to be essential for the development of a Th1 prot ective immune response during Leishmania infection. Hence, we investigated the impact of NETs on monocytes differentiation and in their response to the parasites.

Methods : Supernatants enriched in NETs were generated by activating human neutrophils with Leishmania promastigotes. We monitored the differentiation of NETs- treated or non-treated monocytes into dendritic cells in res ponse to the addition of IL-4 and GM-CSF by flow cytometry and morphology analysis. We also investigated the expression of the IL-4 receptor, molecules associated with macrophage phenotype and the parasite killing by monoc ytes treated with NETs.

Results : NETs-treated monocytes were unable to fully differentiate into dendritic cells. DNase treatment or filtering the traps rescue d the differentiation. NETs closely interact with monocytes and downregulates the expr ession of the IL-4 receptor, a mechanism that may explain the impaired differentia tion of NETs-treated monocytes. Monocytes treated with NETs differenti ated into M2 macrophages as observed by the increase in the expression of CD68, CD32 and CD163 a nd decrease in the expression of CD80. Moreover, NETs-treated monocytes were le ss efficient in kil ling the parasites. Conclusions : Altogether, our results show that NETs interfere with the monocytes response to the parasites, diminishing the formation of monocytes-derived dendritic cells and stimulating macrophage differentiation.

Key-words : Leishmania , Neutrophil Extracellular Traps, Interleukin-4 receptor, CD1a, Monocytes, Dendritic cells Introduction Leishmania sis is a neglected tropical disease transmitted by bites of phlebotomine sandflies. The disease can be manifested in 3 different clinical forms: cutaneous, mucocutaneous and visceral leishmaniasis. Brazil, India, Bangl adesh, Sudan, South Sudan and Ethiopia are responsible for more than 90% of the visceral leishmaniasis reported cases [ALVAR et al., 2012]. A group of ten countries (Brazil, Peru, Colombia, Costa Rica, Algeria, Ethiopia, North S udan, Afghanistan, Ira n and Syria) are responsible for 70 to 75% of reported cutaneous leishmaniasis cases [ALVAR et al ., 2012]. The adverse effects of the drugs used for treatment, the increasing number of resistant parasites and the lack of a vacci ne are still unsolved problems and place the disease as a public health issue.

The infection is initiated by the bite of an infected sandfly, which inoculates parasites along with saliva, r ousing a massive and rapid infl ux of neutrophils, followed by monocytes to the inoculation site, where th ese cells are likely to interact [PETERS et al., 2008; RIBEIRO-GOMES et al ., 2012]. Neutrophils are one of the first lines of defense against invading microbes and the first cells to be parasitized by Leishmania parasites [PETERS et al ., 2008; RIBEIRO-GOMES et al ., 2012]. These cells are endowed with several antimicr obial proteins and can kill microorganisms by the release of the neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) [BRINKMANN et al ., 2004]. NETs are web-structures composed by DNA and pr oteins from different neutrophils compartments, such as histones and elastase, functioning in the contention and killing of microrganisms [BRINKMANN et al ., 2004; URBAN et al ., 2009]. Our group has  demonstrated that Leishmania activate NETs formation, and parasites are ensnared and killed by NETs-associated hi stones [GUIMARÃES-COSTA et al ., 2009]. However, part of the Leishmania population, despite its ability to induce NETs release, evade NETs-mediated killing [GABRIEL et al ., 2010; GUIMARÃES-COSTA et al ., 2014]. Moreover, it was recently desc ribed that saliva of the Leishmania vector, Lutzomyia longipalpis , possesses a potent nuclease that dige st NET’s structure allowing the parasites to escape NET-medi ated killing [CHAGAS, 2014].

Some studies have reported that NETs can orchestrate the immune response during autoimmune diseases and infections [SANGALETTI et al ., 2012; LEFFLER et al ., 2012; LANDE et al., 2007, 2011; GARCIA-ROMO et al., 2011; BRAIAN et al., 2013; KESSENBROCK et al., 2009, HAKKIM et al., 2010]. NETs-activated dendritic cells induce anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) production and autoimmunity in naïve mice, a property prevented by N ET digestion with DNase [SANGALETTI et al., 2012]. NETs were found to be the major indu cer of a type I interferon (IFN) production by plasmacytoid dendritic cells in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus [LANDE et al ., 2011; LANDE et al ., 2007; GARCIA-ROMO et al ., 2011]. Recently, it was demonstrated that NETs formed upon ac tivation of naïve neutrophils with Mycobacterium tuberculosis, interact and activate a proinflammatory response in macrophages [BRAIAN et al., 2013].

Depending on the microenvironment, monocytes can differentiate into dendritic cells (DCs) or macrophages. Thus, dermal infection by Leishmania major leads to the formation of de novo monocytes-derived DCs differentiated in the inflammatory site which are infected by the parasite [LEON et al ., 2007]. Interestingly, dermal- differentiated DCs produce large amounts of IL-12 and stimulate a specific T cell response. It has also been shown that DCs di fferentiated from monocytes at the site of  Leishmania infection constitute the majority of cells producing nitric oxide (NO), an important mediator for parasite killing [DE TREZ et al., 2009]. The inf ection of human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) with promastigotes of Leishmania was found to be restricted to CD14+ monocytes, which in turn leads to the production of IL- 8, CXCL10 and CCL3 [BADOLATO et al., 1996; VARGAS-INCHAUSTEGUI et al, 2010]. Besides, it is interesting to point out that the infection with Leishmania amazonensis impairs human monocytes to different iate into dendriti c cells, weakening the induction of a proper Th1 T cell response [FAVALI et al., 2007]. Here, we asked whether neutrophil extra cellular traps could impact monocytes differentiation into dend ritic cells, affecting the response to parasites. Our results clearly show that NETs impair fully differentiati on of monocytes into dendritic cells by down- regulating the expression of the IL-4 recepto r on monocytes. NETs intimately interact with monocytes and NET-treated monocytes ar e less efficient in killing the parasite. Moreover, monocytes cultured in the presence of NETs e xhibited an in crease in the expression of molecules associated with m acrophages. We envision that NETs can play a role in the orchestration of the early immune response to Leishmania parasites. Material and Methods Parasite Culture Leishmania amazonensis (WHOM/BR/75/Josefa) promastigot es were grown at 26ºC in Schneider’s Insect Medium (S igma-Aldrich), supplemented with 10% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum (FCS; Crypion, São Paul o, Brazil) and 40 µg/mL of gentamicin (Schering–Plough, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil). At da y 5-6 of culture we obtained stationary- phase promastigotes and used throughout the experiments.

Neutrophil and Monocyte Purification  Human neutrophils and monocytes were is olated by density gradient centrifugation (Histopaque; Sigma-Aldrich) from buffy coats of healthy blood donors. PBMCs were collected and washed three times with PB S and resuspended in RPMI medium 1640 (Sigma-Aldrich) supplemented with Nutridom a-CS (1x; Roche Applied Science) and kept on ice until use. The layer containing neutrophil was subjected to hypotonic lysis of erythrocytes. Purified neutrophils (>95% of the cells) were resuspended in RPMI medium 1640 and kept on ice until use. In some experiments, monocytes were purified with the Monocyte Isolation Kit II (Milte nyiBiotec). All procedur es were approved by the Institutional Review Board for Human Subjects (Hospital Clementino Fraga Filho, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, UFRJ).

Production of Neutrophil Extracellular Traps-Enriched Supernatants Neutrophils (8x10 6) were incubated with promastigotes of Leishmania amazonensis in a 1:0.1 neutrophil: parasite ratio at 35ºC/5%CO 2. After 3 h incubati on, supernatant was collected and aliquots were kept at -80ºC unt il use. The quantification of NETs were performed as already desc ribed [GUIMARÃES-COSTA et al ., 2009], with the Picogreen dsDNA kit (Invitrogen, Life Technol ogies). The NETs-enriched supernatants were subjected to treatment with DNase (10 U/mL; Fermentas Life Science), restriction enzymes (ECOR1 and HINDIII, 20 U/each) or with the elastase inhibitor MeOSuc- AAPV-cmk (Calbiochem, 10 µg/ml) for 30 min and then added to monocytes. In some cases, NETs were filtered th rough a 0.22 µm pore filter.

The quantification of the elastase in the supernatants was performed as described [Chagas, 2014]. Briefly, 50 µl of NETs-enriche d supernatants were incubated with the fluorogenic substrate  N-methoxysuccinyl-Ala-Ala-Pro-V al-7-amido-4-methylcoumarin (0.25 mM; Sigma-Aldrich). After 1 h at 37º C, the fluorescence was measured in a  SpectraMax Paradigm reader (Molecular De vices) at 365/450 nm. A standard curve with recombinant elastase was used to dete rmine the concentration of elastase in the NETs-enriched supernatants.

Monocyte-Dendritic Cell Differentiation Assay PMBCs (5x106; 1mL) were incubate d for 2 h at 37ºC/5%CO 2 to allow monocytes to adhere in 24-well plates. Non-adherent cells were washed out and the adhered monocytes were used throughout the experime nts. DNase, filtered or non-treated NETs- enriched supernatants were added a nd cultures maintained at 37ºC/5%CO 2. After 18 h, GM-CSF and IL-4 (50 ng/mL each; Peprotech) we re added and the cultures, which were maintained for 5 days at 37ºC/5%CO 2. Cells were then harvested and stained for CD1a (PE; BD), CD14 (FITC; BD), CD68 (FIT C; BD), CD32 (PE-Cy7; BD), CD163 (APC; BD) and CD80 (APC-Cy; BD). Cells were analyzed on a MACSQuant flow cytometer (Miltenyi Biotec) and data an alyzed with Summit Softwa re 4.3. All experiments with monocytes were done in medium supplemente d with Nutridoma-CS (1x; Roche Applied Science).

Cell viability assay Adhered monocytes were treated or not with NETs-enriched supernatants as described above for 18 h, and lactate dehydrogenase in the culture supern atant was measured according to the manufacturer’s directions (Promega). Briefly, 50 µl of culture supernatant was incubated with 50 µl of substrate mix in a 96-well plate at room temperature protected from light. After 30 min, 50 µl of stop solution was added, and the plate was read at 490 nm on a SpectraMax Paradigm reader.

Immunofluorescence PBMCs (1x106; 1mL) were incubated for 2 h at 37°C/5%CO 2 to allow monocytes to adhere to coverslips. Non-adherent cells we re washed out and adhered monocytes were incubated with NETs-enriched supernatants (2 µg of DNA) for 4h and fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde. Slides were stained with DAPI (10 µg/mL; Sigma), anti-elastase (1:800; Calbiochem) or anti-histone/DNA complex (1:150; Abcam), followed by anti- rabbit-FITC (1:150; Vector Labs) or an ti-rabbit-Texas Red (1:150; Invitrogen), respectively. Epifluorescence images were taken in a Zeiss Axioplan. Phagocytosis and Killing Assay For the phagocytosis assay, promastigotes of L. amazonensis were labeled with the CellTrace™ CFSE Cell Proliferation K it as recommended by the manufacturer (Invitrogen, Life Technologies ). Briefly, promastigotes (1x106 cells/mL) were incubated with 2.5 µM of CFSE in prewarmed (37ºC) PBS. After 10 min at 37ºC, 5 volumes of ice-cold RPMI were added in order to quenc h the staining and cells were incubated for 5 min on ice. Parasites were then washed three times and resuspended in RPMI. Monocytes were treated as described in the Monocyte-Dendritic Cell Differentiation Assay section. After 18h of NET-treatment, monocytes were incubated with CFSE- labeled L. amazonensis promastigotes at a 1 monocyte: 3 parasites ratio. After 4 h of incubation at 35ºC/5%CO 2, monocytes were harvested, washed and cells were analyzed on a FACSCalibur flow cytometer (Becton Dickinson). Data were analyzed with Summit Software 4.3. CFSE-positive monocytes were considered as infected cells. For the parasite killing assay, adhered monocytes were incuba ted with NETs treated or not with nuclease, elastase inihibitor for 18 h at 37ºC/5%CO
2. Promastigotes were

added to the culture in a 1 monocyte: 3 paras ites ratio and the co-culture was maintained  overnight at 35ºC/5%CO 2. Non phagocytosed parasites we re washed out. After 48h of infection, monocytes were lysed with 0.01% SDS  (Sodium dodecyl sulphate) for 5 min at room temperature. Lysis was stopped by addition of Schneider medium supplemented with 10% FCS (Schneider complete medium), and parasites to grow allowed for 48 h. Viable and motile parasites were counted in a Neubauer chamber.

Cytokines Quantitation Monocytes were treated with NETs-enriche d supernatants as described in Monocyte- Dendritic Cell Differentiation Assay section. After 5 days, the cell culture supernatant was collected and kept at -80°C unt il use. Tumor necrosis factor- α (TNF-α), Interleukin-6 (IL-6), Tran sforming growth factor- β (TGF-β) and interleukin-10 (IL-10) concentrations were quantified by ELISA (D uo-Set Kits; R&D Systems) according to manufacturer’s instructions.

Expression of IL-4 and GM-CSF Receptors Adhered monocytes were incubated or not w ith NETs-enriched supernatants (2 µg of NET-DNA), treated or not with nuclease or the elastase inhibitor methoxysuccinyl-Ala- Ala-Pro-Val-chloromethylketone (MeOSu c-AAPV-cmk; Calbiochem) and cultures maintained at 37ºC/5%CO 2. After 18 h, cells were harvested and stai ned with anti-IL-4 receptor α chain (PE; BD) and anti-GM-CSF recep tor (APC; BD) antibodies. Cells were analyzed on a FACSCalibur flow cytome ter (Becton Dickinson) and data were analyzed with Summit Software 4.3.

For real-time PCR quantification of the e xpression of the IL-4 receptor, monocytes (1x106 cells), purified with the Monocyte Isola tion Kit II (MiltenyiBiotec), were treated or not with digested or non-digested NETs-enriched su pernatants. After 4 h of treatment, RNA was extracted from the cell pellets, using the RNeasy mini Kit (Qiagen,  Valencia, CA) and treated with DNase I. cDNA synthesis was performed using the qScript cDNA Supermix (Quanta Bioscien ces, Gaithersburg, MD). Genomic DNA contamination was measured by PCR of total RNA. Relative quantification of the IL-4 receptor expression was performed in a Li ghtCycler 480 (Roche Applied Science, Indianapolis, IN) using the Universal Probe Library system (Roche). Primers (Left: cgtctgcctgttgtgctatg and Right: ggaatctga tcccaccattc) and probe (Probe #9; cat 04685075001) were designed using ProbeFinder software Version 2.45 (Roche). Relative quantification analysis of the target gene versus 18s was performed using the LightCycler 480 software.
Data analysis Unpaired t-test analysis we re performed and p<0.05 was cons idered significant. Data analysis was performed by Gr aphPad Prism 5.03 software.

Results Neutrophil extracellular traps impair fully maturation of monocytes into dendritic cells Neutrophils and monocytes are re cruited to the bite site of Leishmania vectors where these cells play essential roles [PETERS et al., 2008; RIBEIRO-GOMES et al., 2012]. We first asked whether NETs could affect m onocytes differentiation into dendritic cells. Thus, NETs-enriched supernatants (from now on referred as N ETs) generated by activating healthy human neutr ophils with promastigotes of Leishmania amazonensis for 3 h were recovered and kept at -80ºC until use. The conc entration of elastase in our supernatants was 16.10 ± 2.36 µg/ml. NETs containing 2 µg of NET-DNA/3.5 µg of NET-elastase were added to adhered monocytes 1 day before the addition of IL-4 and GM-CSF, and differentiation of monocytes in to dendritic cells was analyzed by the  surface membrane expression of CD1a and CD14 by flow cytometry. Human monocytes are positive for CD14 and negative for CD1a and during the differentiation process in vitro, cells reduce their expression of CD 14 and express high levels of CD1a. Monocytes pre-treated with NETs were unable to fully differe ntiate into dendritic cells as shown in figure 1. NET treatment (44.21% of cells positive for CD1a) reduced 1.7 times the percentage of cells expressing CD1a compared to cells cultivated in medium alone (76% of cells positive for CD1a; Fig1 A,B). The differences are even much higher when we analyzed the mean fluorescence in tensity (MFI) thus, NET treatment (96.45 MFI) reduced 4.8 times CD1a comparing to cell s in culture media (467.3 MFI; Fig 1C). In parallel, we digested the NETs structure with restrict ion enzymes or DNase or we filtered the supernatants. Digestion or filtration of supernatants containing NETs completely rescued the monocytes differentia tion into dendritic cells (Fig 1A-E). The percentage of CD14 + cells decreased 95% in monocyt es derived-DCs (Fig 1D, E).

NETs-treated monocytes showed 7.8 times mo re cells expressing CD14 than monocytes stimulated with IL-4/GM-C SF (Fig 1D). Also, the MFI for CD14 was similar between NETs-treated and untreated monocytes (Fig 1E). Moreover, the supernatants from promastigotes cultured in the same conditions used for NETs generation (SpnLa; Fig 1) and restriction enzymes or DNase (data not shown) treatment had no effect on monocytes differentiation. Treatment with NETs -enriched supernatants was not toxic to monocytes as assessed by extracellu lar LDH measurement (data not shown).

NETs downregulate IL-4 receptor expression Data from the literature has demonstrated that neutrophil elasta se can cleave G-CSF receptor [PIPER et al., 2010]. Since elastase is one of the NETs components, we asked whether NETs could also downregulate the expression of GM-CSF or IL-4 receptors, impairing the differentiation of monocytes into dendritic cells. Figure 3A shows the histograms of IL-4R α and GM-CSFR expression of one representative experiment. Interestingly, a 1.6 times decrease (38% of inhibition) of the α chain of the IL-4 receptor expression was observed in NET-treated monocytes in comparison with monocytes cultured only in medium (Fig 3A-B). Pre-trea tment of NETs with elastase inhibitor or DNase-digested NETs rescued the expression of IL-4R α (Figure 3A-B). We did not observed any differences in th e expression of GM-CSF rece ptors in monocytes treated with NETs (Fig 3A). In order to test if the downre gulation of IL-4R α expression by NET treatment could also be due to a transc riptional regulation e ffect, we performed a real-time PCR for IL-4R mRNA. Our results de monstrated that monocytes treated with NETs expressed 1.8 times less IL-4R mRNA than control monocytes (Fig 3C). Crtl NET Digested 0.00.51.01.5 *CNormalized Expression  NETs-treated monocytes differentiate into macrophages Our results showing that monocytes treated w ith NETs were unable to fully differentiate into dendritic cells led us to wonder whethe r these monocytes were differentiating into macrophages. Light microscopy images reveal ed that monocytes differentiated in the presence of NETs formed a network of a dherent elongated cells, a characteristic of macrophage’s morphology (Fig 4A).

To confirm this data, we analyzed the e xpression of macrophages’ common surface or intracellular markers. We observed that NETs-treated monocytes increased the expression of CD68, CD32 and CD163 in comp arison to control non-treated monocytes (Fig 4B-D). NETs disruption by DNase trea tment diminished the expression of CD32 and CD163 (Fig 4C-D). Moreove r, NETs treatment diminish ed the expression of CD80. Therefore, in the presence of N ETs, cells differentiated to CD68+CD32+CD163+CD80- CD1a-.

We also analyzed the secretion of cytoki nes by NET-treated monoc ytes. As shown in table 1, the ratio of anti-inflammatory:pro -inflammatory cytoki nes were higher in monocytes treated with NETs. This way, the ratio of IL-10:IL-6 and IL-10:TNF- α production by NETs-treated monocytes were 2.9 and 2.6 times hi gher over non-treated monocytes, respectively (Table 1).

NETs-treated monocytes are less e fficient in parasite killing We also evaluated the ability of monocytes to phagocytosis Leishmania promastigotes after treatment with NETs. NETs did not interfere with the phagocytosis of parasites (Fig 5A). However, NETs treated monocytes we re less efficient in parasite killing in comparison to digested NETs-treated monocyt es (Fig. 5B). During the interaction with NET-treated monocytes, parasites survived 1.7 times more comparing to monocytes treated with digested NETs (F ig 5C). Disruption of NETs with DNase treatment rescued the ability of monocytes to kill Leishmania (Fig 5B).

*C Fold over  Discussion Neutrophil extracellular traps formation has b een extensively studied in the last decade. Since the first report, NETs have been suggested to participate in a great number of infectious and non-infectious diseases [BRINKMANN et al ., 2004; COOPER et al ., 2013]. It has been reported by our group and others that Leishmania parasites induce the release of NETs [GUIMÃRAES-COSTA et al., 2009; GABRIEL et al., 2010]. We also demonstrated the presence of NETs structur e in biopsies of patie nts with cutaneous leishmaniasis [GUIMARÃES-COSTA et al., 2009]. However, little is known about the impact of NETs on other immune cells response, which prompted us to investigate whether NETs could affect human monocytes response. Herein we demonstrate that NETs downregulate the expression of the IL -4 receptor in monocytes, prejudicing the differentiation of these cells into immature dendritic cells, and affecting the killing response to Leishmania parasites.

Dendritic cells (DCs) are the primary antigen presenting ce lls and thereby connect the innate to adaptive immune system. During infe ctions, DCs are activated and enter into a process of maturation that invo lves changes in the ability to capture antigens, increased expression of co-stimulatory molecules and migration to secondary lymphoid organs, where DCs activate T cells, controlling th e quality of the Th1/Th2 immune response [ROSSI & Young, 2005; MOSER & MURPHY, 2000]. Dendritic cells play an important role in generating a protective Th1 response during Leishmania infection through the production of IL-12 [GORAK, ENGWERDA & KAYE, 1998]. The control of the infection and the development of re sistance require the production of IL-12, a cytokine largely produced by macrophages and dendritic cells, which contributes to the generation of a Th1 response. Th1 cells produce interferon- γ (IFN-γ), which induces the  expression of inducible nitric oxide syntha se (iNOS) by phagocytic cells, leading to parasite killing [LEON, BRA VO & LOPES-ARDAVÍN, 2007].

The infection of peripheral bloo d mononuclear cells (PBMC) with Leishmania promastigotes was shown to be restricted to CD14+ monocytes cells, which in response to the parasite secrete cytokines such as IL-8, CXC10 and CCL3, recruiting more neutrophils and monocytes to th e site of infection [BADOLATO et al , 1996; VARGAS- INCHAUSTEGUI et al., 2010] . After migration through the endothelium, monocytes can differentiate into macrophages or dendritic ce lls at the infection site [LEON et al, 2007]. The monocyte-derived dendritic cells (mo-DC s) are essential for the formation of a protective Th1 response during Leishmania infection. It has been shown that mo-DCs are formed at the site of Leishmania infection and constitute the main iNOS producing cells, which is important for the eliminati on of parasites [LEON et al, 2007, DE TREZ et al., 2009]. Infection with Leishmania major leads to the generation of two types of mo-DCs: monocytes which migrat e to the dermis and there differentiate locally into DCs and monocytes that differentiate into DCs in the lymph nodes. These two kinds of mo-DCs are among the predominantly infected cells and produce high amounts of IL- 12 to stimulate a specific T cell immune response [LEON et al, 2007]. Impairing the generation of dendritic cells derived from monocytes can prevent the generation of a protective immune response. In fact, during infection by Leishmania mexicana , the recruitment of monocytes to the site of infection is re duced and mo-DCs that are harvested from lesions produce low amounts of NO [PETRITUS et al , 2012]. Furthermore, it was demonstrated that the in vitro infection of human monocytes with promastigotes of Leishmania amazonensis prevents the formation of mo-DCs, affecting the generation of a protectiv e immune response [Favali et al ., 2007]. Our data demonstrate that NETs impair the process of monocytes differen tiation into dendritic  cells. On the contrary, NETs digestion with DNase did not affect this differentiation process. The excessive formation at the site of Leishmania infection or a defect in the clearance of NET-structures could affect the generation of a protective Th1 response, which is important for the infection control. Future studies need to be conducted to evaluate the impact of NETs in generating mo-DCs in the in vivo model of Leishmania infection. We also intend to evaluate the ability of monoc yte-derived dendritic cells (in the presence or absence of NETs) to activat e autologous T, analyz ing the production of IFN- γ.

Dendritic cells can also init iate an immune response by pr esenting glycolipids antigens derived from microorganism s via CD1 molecule. Exposure of monocytes to GM-CSF and IL-4 stimulate the differentiation into de ndritic cells, increasi ng the expression of CD1 molecules [AMPREY et al. 2004]. Infection of human dendritic cells or mo-DCs with L. donovani promastigotes diminishes the expression of CD1 molecules [Amprey et al., 2004; Donovan et al., 2007]. In 2007, Favali and collaborators have demonstrated that the co-culture of L.amazonensis with dendritic cells derived from human monocytes leads to a reduction in the expr ession of CD1a and CD80 and increased expression of CD86 on dendritic cells. Moreove r, infected monocytes produced smaller amounts of IL-6 when compared to uninfected cells [Favali et al., 2007]. Treatment of monocytes with NETs resulted in cells with low expression of CD1a, which could affect the glycolipid antigens presentation.

A likely explanation for the impairment in monocytes differentiation process is the modulation of the expression of receptors for GM-CSF and IL-4. It has been demonstrated that treatment of human neutr ophils with recombinant neutrophil elastase decreases the expression of G-CSF receptor in a time-dependent fashion, as this enzyme can cleave G-CSFR [PIPER et al ., 2010]. Digestion of the receptor was observed by  detection of receptor’s fragments in culture of elastase-treated neutrophils [PIPER et al., 2010]. Since elastase is one of the major com ponents of NETs, we inve stigated its effect in the expression of IL-4 and GM-CSF recepto rs. Interestingly, a decrease in the IL-4R α expression was detected on NETs-treated monocy tes, together with a decrease in the IL- 4R mRNA, indicating that NETs induce not only digestion of the expressed receptor, as well as, exert a transcriptional regulation of this receptor. We have not detected any changes in the expression of GM-CSFR. Dige stion of NETs fully abolished the elastase effect on the expression of the IL-4R on monoc ytes, indicating that NET structure must be intact to be effective. Moreover, this data indicates that de granulated neutrophil elastase would not have the same effect as NETs-associated elastase, since the structural integrity of NETs is required to regulate IL-4R expression.

We have not established here the mechanism by which NETs downregul ate IL-4R expression. However, it was demonstrated that type I interferon and IFN γ diminish IL-4R expression on mononuclear cells and B cells purified from human peripheral blood (SO, PARK & LEE, 2000). It was also demonstrated that both types of IFN posttranscriptionally downregulate IL-4R expression by affecti ng the mRNA stability (SO, PARK & LEE, 2000). Besides, IFN- γ reduces the expression of both γc and α IL-4R chains on human monocytes cell surface (BONDER et al., 2002). Since NETs were shown to be the major inducer of type I interferon producti on by plasmacytoid de ndritic cells during autoimmune disease (LANDE et al., 2007 ), a possible explanation for NETs’ downregulation of the IL-4R would be thr ough the production of IF N by NETs-treated monocytes.

The lower expression of the alpha chain of the IL–4R may have implications in the disease course. The protec tive immune response during Leishmania infection requires the activation of Th1 cells and production IFN- γ, which activate the macrophages’  microbicidal mechanisms. In contrast, the Th2 response with high production of IL-4 and IL-13 is associated with susceptibility to infection. BALB/c mice are susceptible to infection by Leishmania major due to the development of a Th2 response to the parasite. BALB/c mice deficient in IL -4 or with the expression of IL-4R α deleted specifically in CD4+ T cells become resistant to Leishmania infection [KOPF et al ., 1996; RADWANSKA et al ., 2007]. In addition, treatment of Leishmania major - infected mice with soluble IL-4R results in a decrease in parasite load in spleen and lymph nodes, and promoted resistance to reinfection by L. major [GESSNER et al ., Despite the deleterious effect of IL-4 during Leishmania infection, contrasting data have been reported in the literatur e regarding the role of IL-4 during infection. Unexpectedly it has been demonstrated th at administration of recomb inant IL-4 eight hours after infection with L. major promotes IL-12 production by dendritic cells in vivo [BIEDERMANN et al ., 2001]. However, when IL-4 was administered at later time points, C57BL/6 resistant mice become susceptible to L. major infection [BIEDERMANN et al ., 2001]. These data demonstrate that IL-4 has different roles during the course of leishmaniasis. This interl eukin seems to have a protective effect in the early post-infection events . Furthermore, deletion of the alpha chain of the IL-4 receptor on dendritic cells turn BALB /c susceptible to infection with L. major [HURDAYAL et al . 2013], indicating a protec tive role of IL-4 during Leishmania infection. All these studies show that the role of IL-4 in Leishmania remain contradictory. In our study, we have not evaluated the produ ction of IL-4 by monocytes treated with NET. However, these cel ls expressed lower amounts of IL-4R α on its surface. The absence of IL-4 signaling pathwa y in monocytes specifically has not yet been evaluated during Leishmania infection. Our data point to a lower capacity of  monocytes cultured in the pres ence of NETs in the paras ite killing. Further studies needs to be conducted to correlate the e xpression of the IL-4R on monocytes treated with NETs with the monocyte microbicidal capacity. Another fact or that will be interesting to analyze is the effect of NET in the expression of IL-4R α on other immune cells, especially dendritic cells.

Monocytes that were treated with NETs di fferentiated more in macrophages than DCs, with expression of CD68, a macrophage mark er, and classic macrophage morphology (a network treatment of human monocytes wi th GM-CSF increases the production of M- CSF (DELNESTE et al., 2013). of elongated cells with stro ngly adhered to plastic). In our assays we cannot assure that the switch from mo-DCs to macrophages derived from monocytes is due to an increase production of IL-6 and M-CSF or due only to the less expression of the receptor IL-4, which is important for monocytes differentiation into dendritic cells. The production of IL-6 by lo cal cells increases the expression of M-CSF receptors in monocytes that in turn r ecognizes the M-CSF, which estimulates the differentiation of monocytes into macrophages (CHOMARAT et al., 2000). However, in the presence of IL-4 and GM-CSF, monocytes differentiate into dendritic cells (GEISSMANN et al., 1998). Moreover, In our assays, we first treated monocytes with NETs and then IL-4 and GM-CSF are adde d. Since monocytes treated with NETs express less amounts of IL-4R, these cells are being only stimulated by GM-CSF, and this way these cells could be producing M-CSF. This aspect needs to be addressed in future studies.

The analysis of surface markers of differentiated cells in the presence of NETs revealed that NETs-treated monocytes differentiate d into macrophages with a profile of CD32 +CD68+CD163+CD1a- cells. Moreover, these cells have reduced expression of CD80 and increased expressi on of CD163 when treated with NETs, thereby  characterizing a M2 macrophage, according to wh at it is established in the literature (MARTINEZ et al., 2008; JAGUIN et al., 2013). According to th ese data, NETs-treated monocytes have less ability to kill parasite s compared to untreated monocyte. Digestion of NETs by addition of DNase restores the microbicidal capacity of monocytes. Studies in the literature suggest that NETs activate a proinflammato ry response in other immune cells. These structures are capable of ac tivating the production of type I IFN in plasmacytoid dendritic cells and activate the production of proinflammatory cytokines (such as IL-1 β, TNF-α and IL-6) in macrophages (LANDE et al ., 2007, 2011; GARCIA-ROMO et al., 2011; BRAIAN, HOGEA & STENDAHL , 2013). However, different from what it was shown in the li terature, NETs-treated monocytes secreted more anti-inflammatory (TGF- β and IL-10) than pro-inflammatory (TNF- α and IL-6) cytokines. Accordingly, our data also show that NETs-treated monocytes presented a lower parasite killing capacity and genera te M2 macrophages, suggesting that NETs might be activating an anti-inflammato ry immune response in these cells. Despite the ability of parasites to indu ce the formation of NETs, a portion of the population can escape NET-mediated killing. Pa rasites that have escaped NETs will infect other cells, such as inflammatory recruited monocytes, m acrophages and dendritic cells. Upon reaching the site of infection, mono cytes interact with NETs and parasites. NETs decrease the differentiation of monocytes into dendritic cells and at the same time disables the microbicidal mechanisms of th ese monocytes, which di fferentiate into M2 macrophages. The data presented here provid e new information about the role of NETs in Leishmania infection. The reduced expression of IL-4R caused by NETs may result in modulation of the immune response to the pa rasite and thereby alter the course of the disease. Furthermore, the effect in reduci ng differentiation of monocytes and decreasing the expression of IL-4 identified in this wo rk can be applied to any other disease or  inflammatory event where the interaction between neutrophils and monocytes occurs and is relevant. Hence, the re levance of the data presented here is not restricted to infection by the parasite Leishmania .
